channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: US Economy Grew at 2.6% Annual Rate in Q3, GDP Report Shows
item.description: Gross domestic product increased 0.6 percent after two quarters of decline, but key components continue to show an economic slowdown.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: A Rising Dollar Is Hurting Other Currencies. Central Banks are Stepping In.
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes are unsettling global markets and prompting other central banks to prop up their domestic currencies.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a securities firm in Tokyo. Last week, the Japanese yen fell to its weakest level against the dollar since 1990, down more than 23 percent for the year.

item.title: US Mortgage Rates Soar Past 7% for the First Time Since 2002
item.description: The average rate on 30-year mortgages — the most popular kind among Americans — rose to the highest level since 2002, tracking the Federal Reserve’s aggressive campaign of rate increases.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, the most popular kind among U.S. home buyers, rose to 7.08 percent.

item.title: European Central Bank Raises Interest Rates Again
item.description: Policymakers on Thursday approved another hefty rate increase to corral prices that have risen “far too high.”
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Michael Probst/Associated Press
item.media:description: The European Central Bank, which sets monetary policy for the 19 countries that use the euro, raised interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point on Thursday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Likely to Speed, Not Slow, Shift to Clean Energy, I.E.A. Says
item.description: While some nations are burning more coal this year in response to natural-gas shortages spurred by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, that effect is expected to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Martin Meissner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sheep grazing in front of a coal-fired power plant and wind turbines near Luetzerath, Germany, in October, 2022.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Is Sending Leaders to Africa for Help
item.description: Officials from Algeria to Mozambique say they hope to take advantage of an abrupt change in a long-unequal relationship.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Melissa Eddy and Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Andreas Rinke/Reuters
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal welcomed the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in May.

item.title: Putin Wants to Divide Ukrainians. Mykolaiv Is a Test Case.
item.description: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Faces New Challenges With Coalition on Ukraine Support
item.description: The domestic and international consensus has shown signs of fraying as midterm elections loom in the United States and Europeans face the prospect of a cold winter.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden met with Defense Department leaders on Wednesday as the White House signaled Russia remained committed to its war in Ukraine.

item.title: As J.D. Vance Courts Ohio, His Fealty to Trump Proves Double-Edged
item.description: The Republican Senate candidate changed his tune on Donald Trump and now has his endorsement, but a remark by the former president about Vance’s fealty is dogging him in Ohio.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance and Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina meeting with supporters at a campaign event in Beavercreek, Ohio.

item.title: How Mike Lindell’s Pillow Business Propels the Election Denial Movement
item.description: Many American entrepreneurs have mixed politics and business. No one has fused the two quite like the chief executive of MyPillow.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon, Charles Homans and Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike Lindell, the MyPillow chief executive, at a Trump rally this month in Arizona.

item.title: Running Against Hochul, Lee Zeldin Finds Another Target: Alvin Bragg
item.description: Mr. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, has come under withering criticism from the Republican candidate for governor.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, was overwhelmingly elected after pledging during his campaign to stop seeking jail time for certain low-level crimes.

item.title: Chip Makers, Once in High Demand, Confront Sudden Challenges
item.description: Demand for semiconductors was off the charts last year. But a sharp slowdown coupled with new U.S. restrictions against China have created obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Micron plant. U.S. chip makers have pledged huge expansions in domestic manufacturing, betting on a growing need for their products and the prospects of federal subsidies.

item.title: Biden Hopes to Amplify Contrast With Republicans on Economic Policy
item.description: Visiting Syracuse, N.Y., which has benefited from recent legislation, the president will point to his administration’s efforts to lower costs for families.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has struggled in recent weeks to persuade voters to view inflation as an issue that shows the contrast between him and Republicans, rather than a referendum on his presidency and policies.

item.title: Covid, Flu and RSV Are Increasing Hospitalizations in NYC
item.description: New Yorkers are falling ill with new variants of Covid and old illnesses like flu and RSV that masking and other precautions once held at bay.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: New Yorkers waited for Covid bivalent booster shots at Bellevue Hospital this fall.

item.title: Fetterman vs. Oz Is Not Really Fetterman vs. Oz
item.description: About that Pennsylvania debate …
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Tom Gralish/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press

item.title: Kari Lake, Glenn Youngkin and a Post-Trump Era
item.description: What if the post-Trump era has already started? On the trail with Kari Lake and Glenn Youngkin.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Miller
item.media:credit: Ash Ponders for The New York Times

item.title: What Kanye West’s Antisemitism Reveals
item.description: Kanye West’s bigotry should start an honest conversation about the reach of antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Mark J. Rebilas/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

item.title: Protesters So Ill, They Couldn’t Get Arrested
item.description: Long Covid brought attention to M.E./C.F.S., a long-ignored illness whose sufferers are too sick to accelerate research by making trouble the way AIDS activists once did.
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Tufekci
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Therese Russo

item.title: The Climate’s Improved Future
item.description: The world has made real progress on climate change.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Walker Pickering for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines in Western, Neb.

item.title: Is New York (of All Places) About to Go Red?
item.description: Two weeks before Election Day, races across the state have gotten too close for Democrats’ comfort.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Stella Tan, Sydney Harper, MJ Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mary Altaffer
item.media:description: A televised New York governor’s race debate this week. The race, among others in New York State, are closer than many Democrats expected.

item.title: Inside the Minds of Four Grassroots Conservative Voters
item.description: Inside the minds of four American conservative voters, whose political priorities revolve around defending the country.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: A Times Event: How Will World Leaders Address Climate Change?
item.description: Join the head of the World Trade Organization and other global leaders for a livestream of The New York Times Climate Forward event from Egypt.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Kanye West Is Escorted From Skechers Offices, Company Says
item.description: The footwear company said Mr. West, also known as Ye, had been “engaged in unauthorized filming” at one of its corporate offices in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kanye West in Paris this month.

item.title: Shell Reports Earnings of $9.45 Billion, Its Second-Highest Profit
item.description: The two European companies reported earnings totaling nearly $20 billion, partly on higher energy prices as Russia’s war in Ukraine continues.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shell, the London-based energy giant, more than doubled the profit it made a year ago.

item.title: China’s Chest-Thumping Nationalism Now Goes Too Far, Movement’s Godfather Says
item.description: Wang Xiaodong, who helped pioneer China’s nationalist bravado, now fends off criticisms of being too moderate, too cozy with the West, even a traitor. “They’ve forgotten,” he said, “I created them.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wang Xiaodong in a Beijing bookstore in September.

item.title: It Takes a Lot of Elephant Brains to Solve This Mystery
item.description: By counting the facial neurons in African savanna and Asian elephants, researchers made a discovery about the animals’ trunks.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.media:credit: Michael Brecht and Lena Kaufmann
item.media:description: Scientists set out to understand how elephants’ brains enable the manipulations of their trunks and other parts of their faces.

item.title: Do Statins Increase the Risk of Diabetes?
item.description: These cholesterol-lowering medications have gotten a bad rap. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Are Earbuds Damaging My Hearing?
item.description: And if so, are they more harmful than other headphone styles?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Night Sweats Causes: Experts Explain Why You Sweat In Your Sleep
item.description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Celiac Disease Treatment: Are We Close to a Cure?
item.description: Recent advances in understanding the condition have brought a surge of potential therapies to the drug development pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: How Fred Again.. Turns Digital Bricolage Into Dance-Floor Weepers
item.description: The Brian Eno-mentored musician Fred Gibson is amassing a following with tracks built from social feeds and his iPhone. The intricate and emotional results can sometimes even start a party.
item.dc:creator: Foster Kamer
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: The music Fred again.. creates is threaded with sounds culled from the far reaches of YouTube, Instagram and his iPhone camera roll — a sonic bricolage of digitally documented lives.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
